text:
Broadway, West Side, between W. 36th Street and W. 37th Street showing the Hotel Marlborough. It was demolished in 1925.

About 1870

George T. Bagos, Collection
86 Madison Avenue,
New York City.

Broadway, north from W. 36th Street; 37th Street is the intersection seen thru the wagon at the left. In the center, on that side of Broadway prominently appears the Metropolitan Opera House. Note the absence of the Times Building in this view.

About 1900.

N.Y.P.L. Theatre Collection

folder: 36th Street (West) - Broadway - Sixth Avenue, north side, Manhattan, NY
title: 36th Street (West) - Broadway - Sixth Avenue, north side

folder: Broadway - 36th Street, east side, Manhattan, NY
title: Broadway - 36th Street, east side

text:
Broadway, east side, at W. 36th Street, showing the N. E. and S. E. corners. The Greenwich Savings Bank is about to rise on the first mentioned site. Fifteen years from this date will see the lofty Herald Square building on the remaining corner.

Late 1921

John Wallace Gillies
Gift of York and Sawyer

Broadway at the N.E. corner of 36th Street. The corner building will be demolished for the erection of the Greenwich Savings Bank.

Late 1921.

John Wallace Gillies.
Gift of York & Sawyer.

Broadway, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of 36th Street, also showing the north side of 36th Street looking east from Broadway. The corner building will be torn down to make way for the Greenwich Savings Bank.

Late 1921.

John Wallace Gillies.
Gift of York & Sawyer.

Broadway at the N.E. corner of 36th Street, showing also the north side of 36th Street looking east from Broadway. The corner building will soon give way to the Greenwich Savings Bank.

Late 1921.

John Wallace Gillies.
Gift of York & Sawyer.

Broadway at the N.E. corner of 36th Street, showing also the north side of 36th Street looking east from Broadway. The corner building will soon give way to the Greenwich Savings Bank. Late 1921.

John Wallace Gillies.
Gift of York & Sawyer.

Broadway, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of 36th Street. The corner building will be demolished to build the Greenwich Savings Bank.

Late 1921.

John Wallace Gillies.
Gift of York & Sawyer.

Broadway, west side, from 36th to 37th Streets, with the Marlborough Hotel in the foreground. By 1925 this hotel will be replaced by the twenty-story Lefcourt-Marlborough Building.

About 1922.

Wurts Brothers.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.

The Sheridan Building, 1354-1362 Broadway, adjoining the N.E. corner of 36th Street. This and the corner building will soon be demolished for the Greenwich Savings Bank Building.

1922.

Gift of E.M. Jenks.

Broadway, east side, south from 36th Street. In the foreground may be seen the nearly-completed Herald Square Building, for the construction of which the old Seventy-First Regiment Armory has been cut in half.
August 18, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, seven months later. The Herald Square Building is now completed. The flags are at half-staff because of the recent death of Chief Justice and former President William Howard Taft. Mr. Taft was succeeded by Charles Evans Hughes as Chief Justice.
March 10, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

The Herald Square Building site before erection.
February 3, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, east side, south from 36th Street. In the foreground may be seen the nearly-completed Herald Square Building, for the construction of which the old Seventy-First Regiment Armory has been cut in half.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

The Herald Square Building site before erection.
February 3, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, east side, north from 36th Street.
February 5, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Broadway, east side, from 39th to 36th Streets. The clearing in the foreground is on the site of the Casino and Knickerbocker theatres. Below the clearing is the Lefcourt-Normandie Building, on the site of the old Normandie Hotel.
May 10, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, to 37th Street. In the foreground is the Lefcourt-Manhattan Building, a part of which is shown in No. 1 of this group.
May 10, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 2.
May 10, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
